title: Labour conference : Asking me about donations isnt nice , says Lord Alli
body_text:
Labour conference: Asking me about donations isn’t nice, says Lord Alli
The Labour peer at the centre of a sleaze row has told a journalist not to ask him about donations, saying “this isn’t nice”.
Lord Alli, Sir Keir Starmer’s biggest donor, has donated tens of thousands of pounds in clothing and spectacles to the Prime Minister and Lady Starmer, his wife.
He was also granted a rare Downing Street security pass, prompting a “passes for glasses” row.
Lord Alli was spotted at Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool, which has been overshadowed by the revelation, by Sky journalist Serena Barker-Singh.
When Ms Barker-Singh tried to ask him about the donations, he replied: “Please don’t. This isn’t very nice.”
There is no suggestion of wrongdoing on Lord Alli’s part, and The Telegraph has repeatedly contacted him for comment.
05:46 PM BST
That’s all for today...
Thank you for joining our coverage of the second day of Labour’s annual party conference.
We will be back early tomorrow morning to bring you the latest from Liverpool.
05:40 PM BST
Reform membership numbers grow by 5000 since party conference last week
Reform UK’s membership has grown by more than 5,000 since its own annual conference last week, the party has said.
Nigel Farage’s insurgent Right-of-centre outfit had 30,000 members at the start of the year, but this has now passed 85,000 following its gathering in Birmingham last weekend.
It is just shy of the 90,000 that Tory peer Lord Hannan has claimed the Conservatives have.
Zia Yusuf, the Reform chairman, said: “It’s clear Reform has all the momentum in British politics, coming off the back of our biggest and most successful conference yet we are once again showing that we are the real opposition.
“Whilst Labour and the Tories are infighting and losing members, we are setting up national infrastructure at pace and building a campaign winning machine.
“Reform UK are speaking up for the silent majority and they are joining our movement in droves.”
05:31 PM BST
Two thirds say accepting football match and concert tickets is unacceptable - poll
Two thirds of people think it is unacceptable for MPs to accept tickets to concert and football matches as gifts from donors or companies, a new poll has revealed.
More than four in ten people said that the practice was “completely unacceptable”, and 20 per cent believed it was “somewhat unacceptable”, according to YouGov.
It comes after Rachel Reeves’ defending the acceptance of such gifts on BBC Radio 4 this morning, saying that she does not “begrudge ministers or indeed shadow ministers going to a football match or going to a pop concert.”
More than 60 per cent of people believed that wealthy people made donations to individual MPs and candidates because they are trying to “gain influence” over them, rather than just because they support the politician and the party.
05:19 PM BST
Your verdict: Readers’ reactions to Ed Miliband’s conference speech
05:09 PM BST
Reeves hopes there will be no more industrial action ‘going forward’ in NHS
The Chancellor has said that she hopes there will “not be industrial action going forward” in the NHS, despite nurses voting to reject the Government’s pay offer.
Nurses voted to reject the 5.5 per cent pay award, the Royal College of Nursing announced just as Rachel Reeves delivered her speech at party conference.
Speaking at a business event this afternoon, Ms Reeves said: “We accepted the recommendations of the independent pay review bodies… that was important to bring to an end the industrial disputes.
“It was the right decision, in the national interest, also to address recruitment and retention challenges.
“You may have seen the nurses have voted today against the settlement… but my understanding is that is advisory and I very much hope there will not be industrial action going forward in our health service.”
04:56 PM BST
Lord Alli ‘uneasy’ with media attention
Serena Barker-Singh, the Sky journalist who tracked down Lord Alli, said: “He didn’t ask not to ask him about the donations, but he seemed uneasy by the media attention.”
04:18 PM BST
‘Cover up’ illegal sewage dumping and face jail
Water bosses who “cover up” illegal sewage dumping will face jail, Steve Reed has said.
He told Labour’s conference: “We will ban the multimillion pound bonuses water bosses paid themselves for overseeing repeated illegal sewage dumping.
“Bosses who cover up what’s going on will face personal criminal charges – including jail time.
“And we’ll power up the regulator with more staff and give them the teeth they need to prosecute the polluters - and it will be paid for by the polluters themselves.”
04:13 PM BST
Winter fuel rebel ‘disappointed’ by vote delay
Rachael Maskell, a prominent Labour critic of the winter fuel raid, has said it is “disappointing” that a crunch vote on the policy at the party’s annual conference has been delayed, writes Amy Gibbons.
A motion from trade unions opposing the cut – which will see 10 million pensioners lose their allowance of up to £300 – was expected to be debated on Monday afternoon.
This was considered the most likely slot for the vote because it would tie in with a plenary on “growth for higher living standards”.
However, union sources claimed on Monday morning that it had been delayed until Wednesday – after speeches from Rachel Reeves, the Chancellor, and Sir Keir Starmer, the Prime Minister.
Ms Maskell told The Telegraph the vote should have taken place on Monday as “business should follow order”, and described the delay as “disappointing”.
04:02 PM BST
Lord Alli: Don’t ask me about donations row - it isn’t nice
The Labour peer at the centre of a sleaze row has told a journalist not to ask him about donations, saying “this isn’t nice”.
Lord Alli, Sir Keir Starmer’s biggest donor, has donated tens of thousands of pounds in clothing to the Prime Minister and Lady Starmer, his wife.
He was also granted a rare Downing Street security pass, prompting a “passes for glasses” row.
Lord Alli was spotted at Labour’s annual conference in Liverpool, which has been overshadowed by the revelation, by Sky journalist Serena Barker-Singh.
When Ms Barker-Singh trie to ask him about the donations, he replied: “Please don’t. This isn’t very nice.”
There is no suggestion of wrongdoing on Lord Alli’s part, and The Telegraph has repeatedly contacted him for comment.
03:54 PM BST
Ed Miliband channels his inner Nigel Farage
Ed Miliband adapted the Brexit campaign’s “take back control” slogan as he pledged to overhaul the British energy sector.
“In words that will sound familiar, we can, we must, we will take back control of our energy policy.”
03:53 PM BST
Miliband: Labour has won the argument on climate policy
Ed Miliband said Labour had “won the argument” on green policies.
“At the election there was an argument about our country’s future.
“The Tories and their friends on the right said we should turn away from climate action and clean energy. We said no, and we won the argument.
“And I’ll tell you why. Because the British people know our mission to make Britain a clean energy superpower is the way to put energy policy back in the serve of working people.
“Social justice, economic justice, climate justice. That’s the mission of this Labour Government.”
03:52 PM BST
Miliband: British people have the right to benefit from our natural resources
Ed Miliband, the Energy Secretary, told Labour conference: “We believe the British people have the right to own and benefit from our natural resources and friends, we’re making it happen.
“Great British Energy, demanded by this conference, at the heart of our manifesto, overwhelmingly backed by the public, now being delivered by your Labour government. That’s the difference a Labour government makes!
“And friends, my message today is we’ve only just started. Of course the country faces hard times. There is no doubt the Tories have left Britain in a complete mess.
“Hear me when I say this, tough times don’t mean we lower our sights, we raise them.”
03:35 PM BST
Gordon Rayner’s analysis of the Rachel Reeves speech
03:28 PM BST
Welsh First Minister: We have a once-in-a-generation opportunity
Eluned Morgan, the Welsh First Minister, has said it is time to “give hope” to people across the whole of Britain.
“With Welsh Labour Governments in Cardiff and Westminster, we have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to build a fairer, greener and more prosperous future for everyone.
“Let’s seize this moment, let’s work tirelessly to deliver the change that people deserve. Let’s give hope not just to Wales but for Britain, to all who believe in the power of progressive politics to transform lives.”
03:04 PM BST
Labour can ‘finish the job’ and oust SNP, says Sarwar
Anas Sarwar has said Labour can “finish the job” by winning the Scottish general election in 2026.
“The truth is that the story of Labour’s revival is only half written. You see, conference, for lots of you there was only one incompetent government you had to get rid of. But in Scotland we were stuck with two.
“So at the general election we got rid of one incompetent government, and in 2026 at the general election we finish the job and we get rid of the other one.”
02:59 PM BST
Anas Sarwar: We delivered a political earthquake in Scotland
Anas Sarwar, the Scottish Labour leader, received a standing ovation as he started to speak.
“What a year it has been. In the 12 months since we last met, we no longer have a Tory government, we now have the fewest Tory MPs in modern political history, we have the SNP beaten in Scotland and we now have a UK Labour Government that has started the journey for change,” Mr Sarwar said.
“We have, crucially, for the first time in 14 years a Labour Prime Minister. A Prime Minister that understands Scotland, cares about Scotland and is determined to deliver for Scotland. And for the first time ever, we have a female Chancellor in Rachel Reeves who made a fantastic speech earlier today and made clear there will be no return to austerity with a Labour Government.
“And in Scotland we delivered a political earthquake, with a record swing to Scottish Labour. Our share of the vote went up 16 per cent, meaning we now have not one Scottish Labour MP, we now have 37 Scottish Labour MPs putting Scotland at the heart of a Labour Government.”
02:49 PM BST
EDF chief executive: Electricity could be free some parts of the week
Britain’s expansion of green energy could mean electricity becomes free for some parts of the week, according to the chief executive of EDF Renewables, writes Jonathan Leake
Sundays are the most likely day, he suggested, because demand for electricity is usually lowest when many businesses are closed.
Speaking at the Labour party conference, Matthieu Hue said that the surging role and capacity of renewables like wind and solar in the UK’s electricity system meant supply would sometimes exceed demand, driving down prices.
“Demand is not the same every hour of the day, or every day of the week.There are a number of companies, including EDF, who believe that electricity will be free [at some times] - perhaps on a Sunday.”
“This will also be made possible through the installation of smart meters which let people see what energy they are consuming.”
The pledge is reminiscent of the similar promise once often made about nuclear energy - that it would one day produce so much energy that electricity would be “too cheap to meter”. In reality, nuclear power has proven to be one of the most expensive ways of producing electricity.
02:45 PM BST
Labour ‘ripping up the very roots of Thatcherism’
Louise Haigh has said Labour is “ripping up the very roots of Thatcherism” now it is in power, writes Nick Gutteridge.
Ms Haigh, the Transport Secretary, said: “Because of what we achieved together, we are not just cleaning up the mess of the last 14 years, we are ripping up the very roots of Thatcherism that have undermined and run down our transport system for decades.
“Privatisation of our transport is not pragmatism. It hasn’t spurred innovation. It hasn’t made things better. It belongs to a past that failed.”
02:37 PM BST
‘Get on with it’, says Labour MP in nuclear power push
A Labour MP representing West Cumbria has urged ministers to “get on with it” and commit to building more nuclear power plants, writes Matt Oliver amid doubts that they will stick with plans first announced by the Conservatives.
Josh MacAllister, MP for Whitehaven and Workington, said nuclear energy was essential to reaching net zero carbon emissions by 2050 and would create skilled, long-lasting jobs.
He was speaking at a Labour conference panel after The Telegraph revealed a target announced under Boris Johnson for 24 gigawatts of nuclear capacity is being reviewed under Ed Miliband, the Energy Secretary.
Mr MacAllister said: “Where are the next four or five gigawatt-scale reactors going to come from in the next 20 years? Let’s pick the sites. Let’s pick the tech. Let’s get on with it. Let’s give confidence to investors to crowd in behind that.
“You know, we could debate for years which reactor design will be best, but let’s pick and stick and then get the benefits of scale.”
Asked where they should be built, he said: “My community supports it because it creates really good quality, skilled jobs and economic pride. The most popular thing I could do is stand in the middle of Whitehaven and say, ‘We’ve got you a new nuclear reactor’.”
Lord Hunt, the nuclear minister, was also on the panel and stressed the Government’s support for nuclear power, saying: “Does nuclear have a role to play in our future energy structure? The answer to that is yes.”
02:28 PM BST
Labour need to be in power for at least ‘40 years’ to transform working life, trade union official says
A trade union official has said Labour needs to be in power for “40 to 50” years to truly transform working life, Lucy Burton writes.
Speaking to a packed room at a fringe event taking place at Labour conference, Gloria Mills said: “We must remain in power for the next 40, 50 years if we’re going to transform this country. Some people think power is a dirty word. It’s not. It’s how you use power – for too long there has been an imbalance of power.”
Ms Mills added that the “era of rogue employers is over” and said “we must have free, unfettered access to every workplace in this country”.
During the fringe discussion, a group of Unite members stood outside in the rain chanting “Keir Starmer hear us say, tax the rich and make them pay”.
Paul Nowak, the head of the TUC, said Britain is suffering from “an epidemic of low-paid, insecure employment.”
The workers rights plans, which include ending the practice of ‘fire and rehire’ and introducing ‘day one’ workers rights, is a major talking point at today’s conference as the government closes in on publishing its employments bill next month.
02:03 PM BST
‘Nobody can take this Government seriously’, James Cleverly says
Responding to Rachel Reeves’ speech, James Cleverly said: “Nobody can take this Chancellor or this Government seriously.
“Their priorities are all wrong. They talk about taking tough decisions, but capitulate in union negotiations.
“They will tax more and more to spend more and more.
“Labour aren’t taking the tough decisions, they’re making the wrong decisions.
“We can all see that they cannot be trusted with the public finances, or the economy.”
01:56 PM BST
Labour told it ‘can go to hell’ over decision to cut winter fuel payment
Labour was told it “can go to hell” by union activists over Rachel Reeves’ decision to cut the winter fuel payment for millions, Ruby Hinchliffe writes.
Members of Unite gathered at the Albert Dock in Liverpool, despite the pouring rain, to protest against the Chancellor’s controversial policy.
Audrey White of the Liverpool Pensions Association, and a Unite activist, told the crowd: “These aren’t privileges, these aren’t things they should be able to take away.
“These pensioners have worked all their lives.
“I stood there yesterday, and as they [attendees] were walking into the conference, I said 4,000 pensioners – their own figures – are going to die. They smirked at me.
“One of them, when I shouted this, turned round and said ‘good’. The people on the gate were horrified.
“They can all go to hell if they go through with this policy.”
01:43 PM BST
Lift two child benefit cap to help kids lead ‘richer lives’
More unenthusiastic reaction to the Chancellor’s speech has appeared.
Becca Lyon, the head of UK child poverty at Save the Children, said: “If the Chancellor is serious about helping working class kids from ordinary backgrounds lead richer lives, then they need to remove barriers like scrapping the two-child limit to Universal Credit.
“Doing this would lift 360,000 children out of poverty, and many families subject to this are in work – they are part of the working Britain the Chancellor speaks of. Currently the odds are unfairly stacked against these children.
“Rolling out breakfast clubs from April is a good first step, but much more must be done, starting with meaningful targets to reduce child poverty as part of an ambitious strategy.”
01:20 PM BST
‘Growth on its own won’t reduce poverty’
Reaction has been pouring in to Rachel Reeves’s speech just now.
Alfie Stirling, director and chief economist of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, said: “Families who have been struggling to put food on the table and pay their energy bills are not sharing the Chancellor’s optimism today. They want to know when change begins for them.
“Her talk of tough decisions has created a fear of what is to come in the Budget, and a dread that this winter will be as bad, if not worse, than the last. The Chancellor promised an end to austerity, but didn’t signal how she would support families already struggling to make ends meet.
“Across the UK, families can’t wait for economic growth before they feel their situation improve. By failing to repair the foundations, like housing, welfare and public services, that underpin people’s lives the government also risks failing on its own terms to deliver a resilient economy.
“As we have shown today, growth on its own won’t reduce poverty. For the economy to thrive we need to unlock the talent and potential of the millions of people currently trapped in poverty and insecurity. The Budget next month must make tackling economic insecurity - across, incomes, housing and care, as well as work - a top priority of the Government’s mission for growth.”
01:10 PM BST
‘Concerted campaign to whip up fear’ over Rayner reforms
Justin Madders, the minister for employment rights, has said there is a “concerted campaign in the media to whip up fear” over Labour’s New Deal for Working people, writes Eir Nolsøe.
Speaking at a fringe event at Labour Conference alongside union bosses, Mr Madders said some of the headlines in the media on it were “laughable”.
He said: “We know it’s a popular policy.”
It comes despite business groups expressing concerns about some of the reforms.
01:09 PM BST
What you made of Rachel Reeves’s speech
01:06 PM BST
Sign up to the Telegraph Politics Newsletter
Let me be your guide to the important decisions facing MPs and the biggest stories in Westminster, delivered to your inbox for free every weekday.
Sign up to The Telegraph Politics Newsletter to read updates from the corridors of power, must-read opinion from our columnists, amusing cartoons and a standout quote in your inbox, every weekday.
You can register to receive the newsletter for free here
12:56 PM BST
One in eight young Britons ‘not doing anything’
One in eight young Britons are “not doing anything”, according to the employment minister, who warned that lockdown had driven a “rapid” increase in youth worklessness, writes Szu Ping Chan.
Alison McGovern admitted that many young people had been left disillusioned by “politician bull——“, as she hinted Labour would pour more money into mental health and transport services to enable people to get to work.
Ms McGovern said it was “a disaster” and “completely unacceptable” that millions of young people were being left on the scrap heap.
Speaking at a fringe event at the Labour Party conference, Ms McGovern said the number of people not in employment, education or training (NEET) had jumped sharply since the pandemic.
“If you look at the growth recently of young people who are not doing anything - I think we should say it how it is - which is people are being left on the scrap heap. They’re not doing anything in a way that is completely unacceptable and will have a very damaging effect on the future.
“And if you look at those levels, they’ve increased rapidly since the pandemic, and that is not acceptable. That’s about one in eight young people now not doing anything.”
Official figures show half a million young adults are now out of work, with many suffering from the impact of lost and disrupted education since the pandemic.
12:45 PM BST
Rachel Reeves concludes her speech
Rachel Reeves concluded: “We changed our party. Let us change our country. This is our moment, our chance to show that politics can make a difference, that Britain’s best days lie ahead.
“Our families, our communities, our country need not look on while the future is built somewhere else...
“That is a Britain we’re building, that is the Britain I believe in. Together, let’s go and build it.”
12:41 PM BST
Climate Resistance group: We were behind speech disruption
A campaign group called The Climate Resistance has claimed responsibility for the protest which disrupted Chancellor Rachel Reeves’ conference speech.
Sam Simons, a spokesman for the group said: “Labour promised us change - instead we’re getting more of the same. The same pandering to the fossil fuel industry; the same arms licences that are fuelling a genocide in Gaza, and the same austerity that sees the poorest hit hardest.
”It’s time for Labour to start putting the needs of people before the interests of profit. That means immediately stopping arms licences to Israel, blocking new oil and gas, and standing up for the communities already being devastated by the climate crisis.”
12:39 PM BST
Breaking: Reeves’s pay rise rejected by nurses
It is not the news Rachel Reeves will want to come off stage to when her speech finishes.
Nurses have rejected the Government’s pay award of a 5.5 per cent rise, the Royal College of Nursing has announced.
12:38 PM BST
Reeves: We’re building a better Britain
Rachel Reeves received a standing ovation as she said: “This Labour Government will make work pay.
“That is the Britain we’re building, that is the Britain I believe in.”
Ms Reeves said she was proud to deliver the first “meaningful” pay rise for public sector workers in years.
“If the Conservative Party want a fight about who can be trusted with Britain’s public services for those who use them, then I say bring it on. Public services that we can be proud of once again with a Labour Government. That is the Britain that we’re building, that is the Britain that I believe in.”
12:34 PM BST
Reeves: We will create and share wealth across Britain
Rachel Reeves continued: “You will see in your town or your city is a sight that we have not seen often enough in our country.
“Shovels in the ground, cranes in the sky, the sounds and the sight of the future, arriving. We will make that a reality.
“Wealth created and wealth shared in every part of Britain, that is the Britain we’re building, that is the Britain I believe in.”
12:33 PM BST
Watch: Moment pro-Palestinian heckler was removed from Reeves speech
12:32 PM BST
Reeves announces new industrial strategy
Rachel Reeves says that along with Jonathan Reynolds, the Business Secretary, she will publish a new industrial strategy next month.
12:31 PM BST
Chancellor defends winter fuel cuts
“We cancelled road and rail projects promised by the Conservatives which they did not budget for.
“And I made the choice to means test the winter fuel payment so that it’s only targeted to those most in need.
“I know that not everyone in this hall or in the country will agree with every decision that I make. I will not duck those decisions for political expediency, not for personal advantage.”
12:26 PM BST
Reeves: My optimism for Britain burns brighter than ever
Rachel Reeves told Labour’s conference: “I believe in a better Britain, a Britain of opportunity, fairness and enterprise.
“I know that country has sometimes felt far off in recent years as our growth, our productivity and family finances all behind.
“But it doesn’t have to be that way. The British capacity for inventiveness, enterprise, often hard work, has not gone away.
“Believe me when I say, my optimism for Britain turns brighter than ever. My ambition knows no limits, because I can deceases if we make the right choices now... Growth is the challenge and investment is the solution.”
12:24 PM BST
Rachel Reeves defends private school raid as ‘the Britain I believe in’
“We said we would not increase taxes on working people, which is why we will not increase basic, higher or additional rates of income tax, National Insurance or VAT.
“And we will cap corporation tax at its current level for the duration of this Parliament .
“Conference, as promised, we will extend the energy profit levy on oil and gas producers to invest in homegrown energy here in Britain.
“We will end the non-dom tax loopholes, and we will crack down on tax avoidance and tax evasion. That is the difference our Labour Government will make.”
Ms Reeves said her party’s private school VAT raid “is the fair choice, the responsible choice, the Labour choice to support the 94 per cent of our children in our state schools.
“That is the Britain we’re building. That is the Britain that I believe in.”
12:23 PM BST
Reeves: There will be no return to austerity in Budget
Rachel Reeves said: “Next month I will deliver the first Budget of this Labour government.
“And because I know how much damage has been done in those 14 years, let me say one thing straight up. There will be no return to austerity.
“Yes, we must deal with the Tory legacy, and that means tough decisions, but I won’t let that dim our ambition for Britain.
“So real ambition, a budget to fix the foundations, a budget to deliver the change that we promised a budget to rebuild, Britain, and my budget will keep our manifesto commitment. Every choice we make will be within a framework of economic and fiscal stability, you’d expect nothing less.”
12:19 PM BST
Pictured: Protester is escorted out of Rachel Reeves’s speech
12:18 PM BST
Rachel Reeves: Tories promised solutions they knew could never be paid for
“They promised solutions that they knew could never be paid for roads that would never be built.
“Public transport that would never arrive, hospitals that would never treat a single patient.
“They showed no regarding people, and they did not care about the consequences.
“It was made clear to me that failure to act swiftly could undermine the UK’s fiscal position with implications of public debt, mortgages and prices, and so I took action to make the in year savings necessary.”
12:16 PM BST
I am impatient for change but it will be tough, says Reeves
Rachel Reeves resolved to show an “iron discipline” as Chancellor.
“Now I know that you are impatient for change. I am too.
“But conference, because of that legacy left by the Conservatives, the road ahead is steeper and harder than expected.
“You don’t need to take my word for it. Figures released only on Friday showed another month of record borrowing, debt at 100% of GDP, that is the inheritance they left in black and white.”
12:15 PM BST
Reeves mocks ‘clash of the titans’ Tory leadership race
Rachel Reeves mocked the Tory leadership contest, sarcastically calling it a “clash of the titans”.
“Never forget what the Conservatives did years ago today... They cut taxes for the richest, they crushed the economy, sent mortgages spiralling...”
She added: “They do not care, and they have learned nothing.”
12:10 PM BST
Breaking: Rachel Reeves interrupted by hecklers
Rachel Reeves’s speech was interrupted by anti-Israel protesters.
A heckler shouted “and we are still selling arms to Israel!”
Ms Reeves said in response: “This is a changed Labour Party, a Labour Party that represents working people, and not a party of protest.”
12:09 PM BST
Rachel Reeves: I am here because I worked hard
Rachel Reeves told Labour conference: “I am here today because I worked hard. Yes, most of all, I’m here because of the efforts of those who went before me, trailblazing women.
“Jenny Lee, Barbara Castle, our friend and our inspiration. Harriet Harman. And I’m here because of thousands of women, many of you in the hall today, broke down barriers and defeated low expectations to pave the way for the rest of us.
“I am a Labour Chancellor because of that collective endeavour. I am the first woman Chancellor because of that collective endeavour.
“And that collective endeavour does not stop here. It falls to me and to our generation of Labour women to follow in the footsteps of those who went before us, to write the work of all women back into our economic story.
“To show our daughters and our granddaughters that they need place no ceiling on their ambitions. That is the Britain we’re building. That is the Britain I believe in.”
12:07 PM BST
Rachel Reeves: I have fulfilled my promise of becoming first female Chancellor
“In this hall one year ago I stated my intention that the next time I addressed you, I would do so as the first ever female Chancellor of the Exchequer. Today, conference, you can consider that’s a promise fulfilled.
“800 years, the post of Chancellor of the Exchequer has existed, every one a man. On July 5 we made history.
“Every woman watching this will know no matter how high you climb, how hard you work, how qualified you are, there will always be moments when you are reminded some people still do not believe women can get the job done.
“Millions of women in our party, in our trade unions and in every walk of life, beat back those doubts.”
12:05 PM BST
Reeves: I’m ready to deliver on NHS and housing
Rachel Reeves is given a rapturous reception by Labour delegates after an introductory video.
“Conference, thank you. This time last year, I stood on this stage and I made a commitment. I promised that we would get Britain building again, repair our NHS and power growth in every part of Britain.
“Today, after 14 wasted years, I stand here as your Chancellor of the Exchequer, ready to deliver on that commitment.”
Ms Reeves hails more than 200 new Labour MPs, the most diverse Parliament in history and Labour having won in seats like Basingstoke and Hexham for the first time.
“Labour is back in the service of communities we never should have lost in our port, coal, steel and mills towns... And Labour is back in Scotland too.”
11:59 AM BST
Business Secretary: We will build Britain of dignity and opportunity
Jonathan Reynolds, the Business Secretary, concluded: “We can build a Britain, not just of good work and good wages, but of dignity, respect and opportunity.
“The Britain we have always believed in, the Britain we have always strived to build.
“Conference, together for the first time in years, being in government gives us the chance to do exactly that, and I promise, as your Secretary of State, I will work every single moment I have to make that happen.”
11:54 AM BST
Reynolds: I wish we could have done more to help Port Talbot
Jonathan Reynolds, the Business Secretary, said he wished “we could have done more” to save steel jobs in Port Talbot.
But he added: “Working with the unions, we have done more for steel in two months than the Conservative Party did in 14 years.”
Mr Reynolds said the Government was already acting to end late payments and removing barriers that hold back Britain’s high streets.
11:50 AM BST
Not long now
Rachel Reeves, the Chancellor, will give her keynote speech to Labour conference in 10 minutes’ time.
You can follow all the action in my posts and watch Ms Reeves’s speech live at the top of this blog.
11:40 AM BST
Four million homes could be built on green belt
As many as 4m homes could be built on the green belt under Angela Rayner’s planning revolution, analysis shows.
The Housing Secretary’s radical definition of so-called grey belt land could unlock sites for nearly 800,000 new homes across London and the South East alone, according to property data company LandTech.
Hotspots in London’s commuter belt include the Tory constituencies of East Surrey and Orpington, which have potential grey belt sites for up to 115,000 and 89,000 homes respectively.
Ms Rayner is driving a massive shake-up of the planning system in order to achieve Labour’s promise to build 1.5m homes over the next five years.
Melissa Lawford has the full story here
11:25 AM BST
Jonathan Ashworth set to give interview
11:08 AM BST
Tories accuse Labour of hypocrisy over Rayner photographer
The Conservatives accused Labour of hypocrisy after it emerged Angela Rayner has hired a taxpayer-funded “vanity” photographer to chronicle her work in Government.
Simon Walker was reportedly hired on a salary of £68,000, more than twice the national average. He will also take photos for Ms Rayner’s department, the Ministry of Housing.
John Glen, the shadow paymaster general, said: “This is just the latest in a long line of Labour ministers saying one thing and then doing another.
“Labour’s promise to cut the size of the government spin bill was nothing more than empty words, they’d rather spend taxpayers’ money on their own vanity projects than on keeping pensioners warm this winter.
“After scrapping Conservative plans to slim down civil service headcount, Labour should stop pretending that their decision to cut the winter fuel allowance was anything other than a political choice.”
11:05 AM BST
